trans-unit.source: Create and manage a Windows virtual machine in Service Management with Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Create and manage a Windows virtual machine in Service Management with Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure PowerShell to quickly create a new Windows-based virtual machine in Service Management and perform management functions.
trans-unit.target: Use Azure PowerShell to quickly create a new Windows-based virtual machine in Service Management and perform management functions.

trans-unit.source: Create and manage a Windows-based virtual machine in Service Management by using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Create and manage a Windows-based virtual machine in Service Management by using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to create and manage Windows-based Azure virtual machines in Service Management by using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to create and manage Windows-based Azure virtual machines in Service Management by using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Deploy and manage virtual machines using Azure Resource Manager templates and PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Deploy and manage virtual machines using Azure Resource Manager templates and PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Set up Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Set up Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: If you have already installed Azure PowerShell, you must have Azure PowerShell version 0.8.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: If you have already installed Azure PowerShell, you must have Azure PowerShell version 0.8.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed by using this command at the Azure PowerShell command prompt:
trans-unit.target: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed by using this command at the Azure PowerShell command prompt:

trans-unit.source: If you haven't done so already, use the instructions in [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md) to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't done so already, use the instructions in [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](../install-configure-powershell.md) to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Then, open an Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Then, open an Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: First, you must sign in to Azure by using this command:
trans-unit.target: First, you must sign in to Azure by using this command:

trans-unit.source: Specify the email address of your Azure account and its password in the Microsoft Azure sign-in dialog.
trans-unit.target: Specify the email address of your Azure account and its password in the Microsoft Azure sign-in dialog.

trans-unit.source: Next, if you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you need to set your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Next, if you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you need to set your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of your current subscriptions, run this command:
trans-unit.target: To see a list of your current subscriptions, run this command:

trans-unit.source: Now, replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct subscription name and run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Now, replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct subscription name and run these commands:

trans-unit.source: Create a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: First, you need a Storage account.
trans-unit.target: First, you need a Storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can display your current list of Storage accounts by using this command:
trans-unit.target: You can display your current list of Storage accounts by using this command:

trans-unit.source: If you do not already have one, create a new Storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you do not already have one, create a new Storage account.

trans-unit.source: You must pick a unique name that contains only lowercase letters and numbers.
trans-unit.target: You must pick a unique name that contains only lowercase letters and numbers.

trans-unit.source: You can test for the uniqueness of the Storage account name by using this command:
trans-unit.target: You can test for the uniqueness of the Storage account name by using this command:

trans-unit.source: If this command returns "False", your proposed name is unique.
trans-unit.target: If this command returns "False", your proposed name is unique.

trans-unit.source: You will need to specify the location of an Azure datacenter when creating a Storage account.
trans-unit.target: You will need to specify the location of an Azure datacenter when creating a Storage account.

trans-unit.source: To get a list of Azure datacenters, run this command:
trans-unit.target: To get a list of Azure datacenters, run this command:

trans-unit.source: Now, create and set the Storage account by using the following commands.
trans-unit.target: Now, create and set the Storage account by using the following commands.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the names of the storage account and replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the names of the storage account and replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need a cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need a cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have an existing cloud service, you must create one.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have an existing cloud service, you must create one.

trans-unit.source: You must pick a unique name that contains only letters, numbers, and hyphens.
trans-unit.target: You must pick a unique name that contains only letters, numbers, and hyphens.

trans-unit.source: The first and last character in the field must be a letter or number.
trans-unit.target: The first and last character in the field must be a letter or number.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could name it TestCS-*UniqueSequence*, in which *UniqueSequence* is an abbreviation of your organization.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could name it TestCS-*UniqueSequence*, in which *UniqueSequence* is an abbreviation of your organization.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your organization is named Tailspin Toys, you could name the cloud service TestCS-Tailspin.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your organization is named Tailspin Toys, you could name the cloud service TestCS-Tailspin.

trans-unit.source: You can test for the uniqueness of the name by using this Azure PowerShell command:
trans-unit.target: You can test for the uniqueness of the name by using this Azure PowerShell command:

trans-unit.source: If this command returns "False", your proposed name is unique.
trans-unit.target: If this command returns "False", your proposed name is unique.

trans-unit.source: Create the cloud service by using these commands:
trans-unit.target: Create the cloud service by using these commands:

trans-unit.source: Next, copy this set of Azure PowerShell commands to a text editor, such as Notepad:
trans-unit.target: Next, copy this set of Azure PowerShell commands to a text editor, such as Notepad:

trans-unit.source: In your text editor, fill in the name of the virtual machine, the cloud service name, and the location.
trans-unit.target: In your text editor, fill in the name of the virtual machine, the cloud service name, and the location.

trans-unit.source: Finally, copy the command set to the Clipboard and then right-click your open Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Finally, copy the command set to the Clipboard and then right-click your open Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: This will issue the command set as a series of Azure PowerShell commands, prompt you for the name and password of the local administrator account, and create your Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This will issue the command set as a series of Azure PowerShell commands, prompt you for the name and password of the local administrator account, and create your Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of what running the command set looks like:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of what running the command set looks like:

trans-unit.target: Display information about a virtual machine

trans-unit.target: This is a basic task you'll use often.

trans-unit.target: Use it to get information about a VM, perform tasks on a VM, or get output to store in a variable.

trans-unit.source: Log on to a Windows-based virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Log on to a Windows-based virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Run these commands:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can get the virtual machine and cloud service name from the display of the **Get-AzureVM** command.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can get the virtual machine and cloud service name from the display of the **Get-AzureVM** command.

trans-unit.source: Stop a VM
trans-unit.target: Stop a VM

trans-unit.source: Run this command:
trans-unit.target: Run this command:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Use the **StayProvisioned** parameter to keep the virtual IP (VIP) of the cloud service in case it's the last VM in that cloud service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Use the **StayProvisioned** parameter to keep the virtual IP (VIP) of the cloud service in case it's the last VM in that cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If you use this parameter, you'll still be billed for the VM.
trans-unit.target: If you use this parameter, you'll still be billed for the VM.

trans-unit.source: Attach a data disk
trans-unit.target: Attach a data disk

trans-unit.source: This task requires a few steps.
trans-unit.target: This task requires a few steps.

trans-unit.source: First, you use the **Add-AzureDataDisk** cmdlet to add the disk to the $vm object.
trans-unit.target: First, you use the **Add-AzureDataDisk** cmdlet to add the disk to the $vm object.

trans-unit.source: Then you use Update-AzureVM cmdlet to update the configuration of the VM.
trans-unit.target: Then you use Update-AzureVM cmdlet to update the configuration of the VM.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need to decide whether to attach a new disk or one that contains data.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need to decide whether to attach a new disk or one that contains data.

trans-unit.source: For a new disk, the command creates the .vhd file and attaches it in the same command.
trans-unit.target: For a new disk, the command creates the .vhd file and attaches it in the same command.
